entry.title: Popular Summary
entry.summary: Complex system consist of large number of interacting units and it can be modeled as network where nodes reperesent units of the network and links represent interaction between units. For example, we can have network of connected individuals, species, proteins, atoms, etc. Statistical analysis of different…
entry.content:
Complex system consist of large number of interacting units and it can be modeled as network where nodes reperesent units of the network and links represent interaction between units. For example, we can have network of connected individuals, species, proteins, atoms, etc. Statistical analysis of different real-world networks has shown that units are not connected randomlly, but instead there are structural patterns common to different real systems.

If we analyze flow pathways, for example how information move through social system, we can see that there are subgroups of nodes where flow stays for relatively long time. This indicates that network has community structure. Detecting community patterns give us important information about organization and function of the real system.

One problem, however, is that empirical data we use to construct complex network often contains errors, so information about interacton between some units can be missing. The noise in network structure can induce the error in description of communities that futher give us misleading information about the system. 

To reduce error in community detection in noisy networks with missing links, we developed method that incorporates prior assumption about network flows in the flow-based community detection method known as the mapequation. The method uses prior assumption of the network with random connections and without community structure. The mapequation successfully balance the impact of the imposed prior against the observed network data and in the case when there is good signal in the network structure it detects communities successfully. However, if the large fraction of links is missing it indicates that the level of noise is high and significant community structure can not be detected.

entry.title: Visual abstract
Jelena Smiljanić
entry.summary: I am Postdoctoral Researcher at Integrated Science Lab at Umeå University. My research focuses on applying statistical physics, complex networks theory and data science techniques, to study how different real-world systems are organized.
entry.content:
I am Postdoctoral Researcher at Integrated Science Lab at Umeå University. 

 

 

My research focuses on applying statistical physics, complex networks theory and data science techniques, to study how different real-world systems are organized.

entry.title: Research
entry.summary: Organization of complex systems is governed by different underlaying principles, and theory of complex networks provides us useful methods to reveal them. The first step within this framework is to extract individual elements of the system and to represent interactions between these elements in the form of complex…
entry.content:
Organization of complex systems is governed by different underlaying principles, and theory of complex networks provides us useful methods to reveal them. The first step within this framework is to extract individual elements of the system and to represent interactions between these elements in the form of complex network. After this step, the study of complex system organization is reduced to the analysis of structure and dynamical processes on network with the use of suitable methodology. The increase in a variety of real systems with available data, which enable insight into the structure of network of interactions, requires constant development of new techniques and theoretical models that could explain behavior of specific systems.

During my PhD, I studied complex networks with discrete dynamics using data on event-based social systems. The research focus was on participation patterns in events organized by different social groups. The analysis has shown interesting regularities in participation dynamics and I made mathematical model that can explain them. 

My current research interest is related to development of methods for describing significant community structure of complex networks.

entry.content:
Journal papers:
  • M. M. Dankulov and J. Smiljanić: “The Structure and Dynamics of Meetup Social Networks”, in Scientific Computing, Chapter 2, Pages 33-61 (Nova Science Publishers, New York, 2017).
  • J. Smiljanić and M. M. Dankulov: “Associative nature of event participation dynamics: A network theory approach”, PLoS ONE 12, e0171565 (2017).
  • J. Smiljanić, A. Chatterjee, T. Kauppinen, M. M. Dankulov: “A Theoretical Model for the Associative Nature of Conference Participation”, PLoS ONE 11, e0148528 (2016).
  • I.E. Stanković, M. Žeželj, J. Smiljanić and A. Belić: “Modeling of Disaster Spreading Dynamics”, Springer Book Series on Modeling and Optimization in Science and Technologies 2, 31 (2014).
  • J. Smiljanić, M. Žeželj, V. Milanović, J. Radovanović and I. Stanković: “MATLAB-based program for optimization of quantum cascade laser active region parameters and calculation of output characteristics in magnetic field”, Computer Physics Communications 185, 998 (2014).
  • J. Smiljanić and I. E. Stanković: "Efficient Routing on Small Complex Networks Without Buffers", Physica A 392, 2294 (2013).
  • J. Smiljanić, M. Žeželj and I. E. Stanković: "Study of routing strategies in the small complex networks", Telekomunikacije 10, 54 (2012).

 

Conference papers:
  • J. Smiljanić and M. Rosvall: “Mapping undersampled networks”, NetSci (2018), Burlington, Vermont, USA.
  • J. Smiljanić and M. Rosvall: “Identifying significant flow-based communities in undersampled networks”, SINM, NetSci (2018), Burlington, Vermont, USA.
  • A. Alorić, A. Vranić, M. M. Dankulov and J. Smiljanić: “Collective social phenomena: physics perspective”, West Balkan Data Science Workshop (2018), Belgrade, Serbia.
  • M. M. Dankulov and J. Smiljanić: “Associative nature of event-driven social dynamics: a network theory approach”, COMPLEX NETWORKS (2017), Lyon, France.
  • M. M. Dankulov and J. Smiljanić: “Structure and Dynamics of Event-driven Social Groups”, TINKOS (2017) , Belgrade, Serbia.
  • J. Smiljanić and M. M. Dankulov: “Associative nature of conference participation dynamics: an empirical analysis and modeling”, TINKOS (2016) , Belgrade, Serbia.
  • J. Smiljanić and M. M. Dankulov: “Associative nature of conference participation”, MECO (2016) , Vienna, Austria.
  • J. Smiljanić and M. M. Dankulov: “Conference Attendance Patterns”, SFKM (2015), Belgrade, Serbia.
  • Igor Stanković, Milan Žeželj, Jelena Smiljanić, “Numerical Simulations of the Structure and Transport Properties of the Complex Networks”, HP-SEE User Forum (2012), Belgrade, Serbia.
  • I. Stanković and J. Smiljanić: “Structure of complex networks for minimizing traffic congestion and cost”, DPG (2012), Berlin, Germany.
  • J. Smiljanić and P. Ivaniš: “Attacks on the RSA cryptosystem using integer factorization”, TELFOR (2011), Belgrade, Serbia.

entry.title: About me
entry.summary: Postdoctoral Researcher Integrated Science Lab Department of Physics Umeå University, Sweden Email: jelena.smiljanic@umu.se I was born in Serbia where I received my bachelor’s and master’s degree in telecommunications from the University of Belgrade. After finishing master studies, I started my research career at the Institute of Physics Belgrade. My research interests focus on…
entry.content:
Postdoctoral Researcher
Integrated Science Lab
Department of Physics
Umeå University, Sweden 

 

           Email: jelena.smiljanic@umu.se 

 

I was born in Serbia where I received my bachelor’s and master’s degree in telecommunications from the University of Belgrade. After finishing master studies, I started my research career at the Institute of Physics Belgrade. My research interests focus on applying statistical physics, complex networks theory and data science techniques, to study how different real-world systems are organized. I received my PhD from the University of Belgrade in 2017. In my dissertation, I have analyzed the interplay between network structure and the dynamics of event-driven social groups.

I joined Icelab as a postdoctoral researcher in August 2018 and started to work on dealing with uncertainties in community detection algorithms.

 

Naturvetarhuset, byggnad G, NA plan 3, IceLab Umeå universitet, 901 87 Umeå
